content.description:
Climb cracks in shallow left facing inside corner to small roof. Surmount roof and finish on the overgrown top of the pedestal.

 This is #44 in Swartling/Mayer and is listed simply as "Unnamed 5.7" in Knower.
content.location: On the half-height pedestal about midway between Big Toe and Son of Great Chimney. Start in left facing inside corner under a small roof and about 5' left of Icarus.

content.description: Start in the north inside corner of the recessed section, climb 15 feet to the first ledge. Then up a crack to the base of a narrow chimney. Climb Chimney (crux) to the ledge above. Pull up over the overhanging ledge and finish in 12 foot inside corner
content.location: Right near Great Chimney. Just to the right of Double Jeopardy.

content.description: This was a old aid line, called Bivouac Ledge 5.7 A1, starts about 10ft left of the start of SOGC, climb up to ledge with boulder below overhang, pass overhang and move right to crack to Bivouac Ledge, then work your way to the top,

Start up the 10- slab to the left of Homo Erectus.  Cruise to the base and up the right side of the wall, through horizontals at the bottom and in middle of the overhanging wall above.  Long reaches, a key hand slot, and a  lucky catch gets you to a finishing mantle, followed by a couple of satisfying 5.8 moves in the upper short dihedral to the top.
content.location: The small amphitheater to the left of Homo Erectus has four climbs with Modern Life is Rubbish on its left edge.  To the right of this is Mr. Lucky.  The right crack filled with pigeon poo is Foie Gros (5.7), and the right wall is Coup de Gras (510a.  Similar to Coup d' Etat, but obviously easier).

content.description: The crux is an overhanging crack that climbs up into a notch chimney, a   nice hand crack leads to big jugs to get climber into the notch above at a reasonable grade.  The small chimney has a hand crack at the back that leads up and climber escapes to ledge on the right and surmounts a final nifty but short corner.
content.protection: Protection is excellent all the way with a standard varied DL lead rack and especially well protected at the crux overhanging crack section.
content.location: Route 41 page 272 of 3rd edition of Climber's Guide to Devil's Lake.  Climbs up the bulbous and hanging buttress that lies between the route "Grand Illusion" to the left as climber looks up from below and route "Homo Erectus" to the right.  Unless you work your way up to the ledge system at mid cliff height as the guide suggests you need to climb up the pine needle ridden and tree limb obscured crack and ledge system that leads directly to the gnarley Cedar tree that lies just below the crux section on the a-formentioned ledge system. Don't let the mossy look of these lower moves and cracks scare you off..  it's good climbing with fun finger locks and mantle moves onto the periodic ledges.

content.description: This route ascends finger ripping blades all the way up.  First move slaps the corner, and then no rest till a good shake prepares for (what else?) blades to the finish. A variation at 11a goes up the arete using a few blades to the right and the punky holes and detached flakes on the corner.
content.location: The north facing wall on the right side of the block with Homo Erectus.  Start up easy or hard ground to get to the sloping grassy ledge.

content.description: Climb the chimney on North side of the pointy nose. Climb ended 20 feet early due to the vegetation.
content.protection: TR or medium to small gear
content.location: The chimney directly right of Grand Illusion.

content.description: A complicated boulder problem, with lots of parts.
content.location: In the middle of the outer face, on the pedestal left of "Double Jeopardy"

climbs.name: Homo Erectus
climbs.fa: Alex Andrews on TR, Kris Gorny on lead

content.description:
Ascend ledges 15ft to the tree and climb the obvious weakness in the middle of a steep face. Scarce pro on the bottom, decent small pro just before the crux. Sizeable runout through the crux. Little tricky but fun moves overall. 

  Not sure what the name is and whether this has been led or TR'd before or by who. Any info would be appreciated!
content.protection: BD C3's and Wild Country Ultralights (or equivalent).
content.location: Buttress mid between Stuck Knee and Grand Illusion. See beta pictures below.

content.description: Climb the northeast corner of the tall blunt buttress. Is it called The Heel because it is located behind the Big Toe or because, as mentioned in Swartling, the climb involves an interesting heel hook?
content.location: located on the southern end of the Big Toe to Great Chimney area. Approach from the south and pass the Big Toe routes. The climb is found up and right of Big Toe Right, and up and left of Grand Illusion.

content.description: In Swartling's guide the route is shown as starting of ledge DD at Prospect Point Rampart.   This is true but a better and more fun option is to climb the route from the ground via the 5.10b variation start that is a goody in itself (although can be wet and gooey right at the base).   The upper Grand Illusion part of the route proper is a gem too.  Very nice crack up into a overhanging crack/groove.  Well protected and classic stiff 5.9.  The crux here is pulling through the overhanging crack via locks and a throw to sharp jugs (all after hang'n out below it and placing gear).  If you fall - no problem- it is pure air.
content.protection: All bomber natural chocks (big wires), tricams, and cams.
content.location: Approximately at left end of Prospect Point Rampart wall proper.  Variation start from base is right of Big Toe formation.

content.description: Climb the inside corner between Mr. Lucky and Coup de Gras. Dirty climbing on the lower inside corner leads to a large ledge and cleaner inside corner climbing above the ledge.
content.location: Obvious inside corner about 50' north of the Big Toe. In Swartling/Mayer, it is route #42 and starts from the EE ledge. In Knower, it is a named route that starts at a deep inside corner at the base of the wall, climbs up to the EE ledge, and continues on the inside corner above EE ledge.

content.description: Double Jeopardy is just south of the Great Chimney and is somewhat easily located.  Look for the most inviting dihedral amongst about 4-5 dihedrals on this wall.  About 25 feet up there is a large tree growing from a ledge.  Start out on easier terrain.  Once you reach the tree the angle steepens.  The first real diffuculty occurs below a hanging chimney.  Go left of the chimney and surmount a large ledge with a dead fallen tree trunk on it.  Pass the trunk and find the crux, a steep face which can be a bit of a puzzle to figure out.  If leading, be sure to use your slings wisely to avoid rope drag.
content.protection: Standard rack with a couple long slings.

content.description: It is of a sustained 5.9 nature of climbing.  Pulling over the little ledge near the top is maybe the most physical move.  Resisting stemming over to the left hand wall is the mental crux.  The climbing is a bit harder if you don't stem over and keep both feet on the right wall.  Nice finger locks in the crack section at 3/4 height  below the little ledge with the angular shaped block sitting on it.  The first 30 feet has some very mildy loose flakes and somewhat fragile rock but it is for the most part OK.  This climb is "named" due to the similar nature of the rock and the rock climbing to another well know DL classic albiet quite a bit easier.
content.protection: Pretty good gear between small to mid sized stoppers and cams at about every body length.  It gets better as you climb higher.
content.location: West Bluff... West Rampart... Big Toe to SOGC area.  Situated between routes "Foie Gros" and "Homo Erectus".  Get up to halfway ledge system in this area any which way you like....

content.description:
The right line of 2 lines that ascend the North (or NE) face of Big Toe, just right of the Big Toe route on the corner and left of the obvious 5.2 chimney.

 This is a named route in Knower's book and is unnamed #28 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Access is the same as Big Toe. Work your way through the large boulders near the bottom of Big Toe to reach the start of Big Toe Right and beyond to the rest of the rampart.

content.description:
The left line of 2 lines that ascend the North (or NE) face of Big Toe, just right of the Big Toe route on the corner.

 This is a named route in Knower's book and is unnamed #27 in Swartling/Mayer.
content.location: Access is the same as Big Toe. Work your way through the large boulders near the bottom of Big Toe to reach the start of Big Toe Left and beyond to the rest of the rampart.

content.description:
Start behind cobra head-shaped tower and climb the corner to large platform.

 This is a named route in Swartling and Mayer. Not listed in Knower's book.
content.location: Descend access route from West Bluff Trail down to 2nd ledge below Prospect Point Pinnacle. Turn north past the start of Prospect Point Pinnacle East Face route, and pass the start of Creamy Caesar. Don't descend too far and too soon to the right or you'll end up at the base of the Dark Wall. If you stay left you'll dead end in an area where you can scramble up to the top of the Big Toe platform. A little before the dead end, you should angle down and right to get to the bottom of the Big Toe routes, all the Prospect Point Rampart routes beyond, and the Lost Face routes beyond that.

content.description: From pine tree climb up thin crimps on face to the break.  From break fire the crux sequence to jugs up and right.  Top-out straight up.
content.protection: Could take good gear at the break, but thats about it.
content.location: On face between Double Jeopardy and Stuck Knee.

content.description: Climbs in between Prospect Point Pinnacle and Great Chimney, along the upper wall.
